original_conversation.content:
[frustrated] I can't believe this is happening. Twenty-three years of practice, and now... this. Mrs. Henderson's bunionectomy was textbook—I mean, I've done hundreds of these procedures, and hers went perfectly. [sigh] Every single step was by the book. The incision, the bone realignment, the—everything. And now she's claiming I, what, damaged her nerve? 

[anxious] The thing is, um... I documented everything. Like, obsessively. Her pre-op x-rays showed severe hallux valgus, the surgery notes are detailed, post-op healing was normal. But apparently her lawyer thinks, I don't know, that we somehow caused this numbness she's experiencing? [bitter] Which, by the way, I explicitly warned her about as a possible complication. It's right there in the consent form she signed.

[shaky voice] My insurance company wants to settle. Can you believe that? They're basically saying, "Yeah, just pay her off," like I actually did something wrong. But I didn't—I know I didn't. [angry] This is my reputation we're talking about here! 

The worst part is, hmm... I keep second-guessing myself now. [quietly] Every procedure, every patient, I'm wondering if they're going to turn around and sue me too. It's like, er, how am I supposed to practice medicine when I'm constantly looking over my shoulder?

subject: Your podiatrist practice is being sued for malpractice over a procedure you know you performed correctly
